electricity could be converted into fuels or value-added chemicals through electrochemical water splitting, CO2, or N2 reduction, and reconverted into electrical energy through fuel cells. Toward this end, the development of high-performance electrocatalysts would play a crucial role for the key chemical reactions involved, including oxygen reduction reaction (ORR), hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), oxygen evolution reaction (OER), carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR), and nitrogen reduction reaction (NRR).[2]
Currently, the metal-based catalysts, including noble metals (Pt, Ru, and Rh)[3] or non-noble metals (Co, Fe, Ni, and Cu),[4] have been extensively demonstrated to be effective for these energy conversion reactions. To further reduce the cost and improve the catalytic performance for
widespread applications, these metal particles are normally dispersed on appropriate supports. This not only can increase the number of accessible active sites by reducing the particle sizes, but also can manipulate the electronic properties of the metal particles, thus leading to the improvement in their instinct catalytic activity.[5] Recently, researchers have proved it was possible to maximize the atom efficiency by downsizing the metal catalytic center to atomic scale.[6] In this system, every individual metal atom is accessible and catalytically active, which could be defined as the single-atom catalysts (SACs).[7]
For traditional heterogeneous catalyst, it is difficult to rigorously study the synergistic effect from the substrate, because the catalytic performance also highly depends on the composition, structure, size, and shape of the metal particles. But the SACs contain only isolated metal atoms that are dispersed on supports without appreciable interaction between each other. The well-defined active center makes it easier to understand the interaction between singe metal atoms and the supports from both theoretical and experimental perspectives. In fact, the SACs are not really isolated atoms, as the catalytic activity and stability in SACs are originated from the unique coordination structures between the single metal atoms and neighboring nonmetallic atoms on the support. In other words, the composition and structure of the support become more dominant for tuning the catalytic properties of SACs.
Single-atom catalysts (SACs) on 2D nanomaterials have great potential as efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts for clean energy technologies. The coordination environments, as well as the physicochemical properties of the 2D supports, play key roles in tuning the catalytic activity and reaction mechanism of the single-atom centers. This review first summarizes the suitable synthetic strategies of single-atom on different 2D supports. The methods that facilitate the formation of relative homogeneous structure and enable the regulation of the surrounding atomic environment of metal center are discussed. Furthermore, the recent progress of SACs for energy-related electrochemical applications is reviewed, including oxygen reduction reaction, hydrogen evolution reaction, oxygen evolution reaction, CO2 reduction reaction, and nitrogen reduction reaction. The strategies about modulation of the electronic structure of single-atom for enhanced performance are highlighted, together with a discussion of the current issues and the prospects of this field.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
As the energy and environmental issues are ever increasingly serious nowadays, the exploitation of renewable and clean energy technologies has aroused considerable research interests. Electricity from solar or wind energy is in principle able to meet a large portion of the global energy demand. However, it is intermittent and efficient and economical storage and utilization pathways are required.[1] In an ideal energy cycle,

2D nanomaterials, such as graphene,[8] exfoliated graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4),[9] molybdenum disulfide (MoS2),[10] layered metal organic frameworks (MOFs),[11] and covalent organic frameworks (COFs)[12] have been explored as the support of SACs for electrocatalytic applications. The utilization of 2D materials can offer many advantages: 1) The density and accessibility of single atom active sites could be maximized on the uniformly exposed 2D surface; 2) the single atomic sites could be clearly characterized on the simple and ordered 2D structure; 3) the unique properties and tunable electronic structure of 2D materials enable the controllable modulation of the chemical environment surrounding the single metal center for synergistically enhanced electrocatalytic performance. By the combination of density functional theory (DFT) calculations and advanced X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) technology, the geometric configuration and electronic structure of SACs in 2D materials can be unambiguously identified.[8b,13] It helps understand how the structural change in support affects the catalytic activity and reaction mechanism involved. Furthermore, the research of 2D materials about the structural regulation and structure–activity relationship for electrocatalysis has boomed up since the discovery of graphene.[14] These researches can contribute to the study on site-support synergistic effect and may give some new insight or guidance for the design of future generations of SACs.
Despite that the research on the modulation of electronic structure of SACs is in its infancy, some inspiring achievements have been achieved, especially in the activity control and stability enhancement for electrochemical applications. Although some excellent reviews articles have been devoted to the preparation and application of SACs,[6c,7,15] the modulation process of the electronic structure for enhanced electrocatalytic performance has not been summarized in detail. In this review, we first introduce the suitable synthetic strategies for SACs base on different 2D supports, followed by a discussion section about the electronic modulation process. The electrochemical applications are then summarized, which mainly focus on electrochemical ORR, HER, OER, CO2RR, and NRR. The research works involving the discussion about the modulation of electronic structure of supported SACs are highlighted. We aim to provide a succinct but comprehensive understanding of SACs about the electronic modulation induced performance enhancement for energy-related electrocatalysis.

sections.heading: 2. Synthesis of SACs in 2D Materials
sections.text:
For the SACs in 2D materials, the strong interaction with the substrate guarantees the stability of isolated metal atoms and manipulates its catalytic performance. Therefore, rational selection of the suitable substrate and optimization of synthetic procedures play key roles in tuning the site–substrate interaction and realizing high catalytic activities. As mentioned above, 2D materials have unique advantages as the SACs substrates. The preparation, characterization, and structural manipulation of various 2D materials have also been largely explored by many excellent works. According to the difference in structure and composition, the synthetic strategies of SACs in 2D frameworks
can be varied, mainly including the pyrolysis, wet chemistry synthesis, ball milling, and external field-assisted method.

sections.heading: 2.1. SACs in Graphene Frameworks
sections.text: Graphene is the 2D nanosheet consists of sp2-hybridized carbon atoms perfectly arranged in a honeycomb lattice. It is also the basic building block for carbon nanotubes and many other carbon allotropes. The extended π conjugation network grants graphene high chemical stability and good conductivity, which make it an attractive platform for electrocatalytic application.[16]

sections.heading: 2.1.1. Pyrolysis
sections.text:
Undoped graphene is seldom considered as support to disperse single atoms, due to the relatively weak anchor ability of C atom for metal atoms. Recently, Zhang et al.[17] reported that the graphene defects could be employed to trap Ni atom through the pyrolysis of as-prepared defective graphene and Ni salt at 750 °C followed by acid etching in 1 m HCl to remove the Ni particles, forming atomic NiC4 species with a high Ni loading of 1.24% (Figure 1a).

In most cases, the heteroatoms, especially N, S, and O, are usually introduced as coordinating sites. Thermal decomposition of the mixture of metal-, nitrogen-, and carbon-containing moleculars or polymer precursors at elevated temperatures is a common way to synthesize N coordinated single metal atoms (MNx, M = Co, Fe, Ni, and Pt) embedded in graphene matrix (Figure 1b).[18] Similarly, other SACs embed in graphene matrix, including Mo or W SACs anchored with nitrogen and carbon atoms (Mo1N1C2 or W1N1C3) and Pt SACs anchored with four sulfur atoms (PtS4), have also be prepared.[19] But in many cases, some carbon-wrapped metal by-products are simultaneously formed during pyrolysis, which cause the reduction in the number of single atom sites and make the catalyst structure more complex. The addition of S or Si element in precursors can efficiently alleviate this drawback for Fe-based sample preparation.[20] By in situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy analysis, Sa et al.[20] suggested that the interaction with the silica layer on carbon surface stabilized the FeN4 site and prevented its agglomeration to Fe particles. Zhu et al.[18b] reported a NaCO3-assisted pyrolysis strategy to obtain PtN4 site supported on graphene with a high Pt loading of 5.3 wt%, in which the NaCO3 was responsible for the formation of ultrathin 2D support. Pyrolysis of graphene oxide (GO) and metal ion under NH3 atmosphere is a general approach to synthesize MNx SACs embedded in N-doped holey graphene framework (Figure 1c). Sometimes the NH3 not only serves as N resources and protective atmosphere, but also can adjust the surface polarities and porosity of the support to improve catalytic performance. Typically, the metal atoms are anchored on the oxygen-containing functional groups of GO through liquid phase agitation or hydrothermal method. After freeze drying, the mixture is heated under NH3 atmosphere to obtain the final samples. By reasonable controlling of the ratio of metal ion, the formation of metal nanoparticles can be effectively avoided.[8b,21] Fei et al.[8b] reported a series of single metal atoms (Fe, Co, and Ni) embedded in the graphene support of relatively ordered structure. Besides, other Fe, Co, Ni, and Ru SACs supported on graphene have also been obtained through the above method.[22] Qu et al.[23] reported a scalable approach to obtain carbon-supported CuN4 sites with the assistance of NH3. In this process, the bulk Cu was first converted into volatile Cu(NH3)x species under NH3 atmosphere and then trapped by the as-prepared N-doped carbon to form isolated copper sites.
The morphology, pore structure, and surface area of the support of SACs are significant for mass-transfer during electrochemical reaction. Incorporation of sacrificial templates during pyrolysis, such as magnesium oxide (MgO), silica nanospheres, and ordered mesoporous silica SBA-15, can effectively modulate these parameters.[24] Thomas and coworkers[25] reported the synergistic utilization of two types of templates, FeCl3·6H2O and silica nanoparticles, to achieve 2D hierarchically porous carbon nanosheet with atomic FeCoNx moiety (Figure 1d). The FeCl3 can coordinate with the carbon precursor (dopamine hydrochloride) to form a layered hybrid structure, which serves as 2D template, Fe resource, and the porogen for micropore at the same time; and the silica nanoparticles mainly contribute to the formation of a large number of mesoporous. Zhi and co-workers[26] used zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIF)-8 modified graphene as template to synthesize single-site FeNx moiety on 2D hybrid architecture. During pyrolysis, the ZIF-8 was transformed into a thin porous carbon layer on the graphene surface to ensure the uniform dispersion of the active sites. The graphene interlayer with high conductivity may boost the charge transfer capability for electrocatalysis.

sections.heading: 2.1.2. External Field-Assisted Method
sections.text:
The unique π-conjugation structure endows graphene with good electrical conductivity and microwave absorption property, which provide the precondition and foundation to
electrochemical and microwave-assisted method for SACs synthesis. Different from many other synthetic methods that suffer from scalability issue or the requirement of special instruments, the external field-assisted synthetic strategies toward SACs usually have the advantage in time- and energysaving and are easy to operate.
Electrochemically Assisted Method: It has been found that Pt atoms can be dissolved under certain electrochemical circumstances and deposited onto counter electrode as nanoparticles or nanoclusters. If the electrodeposition time or potential cycles times are carefully controlled, the atomic-level deposition of Pt can be realized. By this strategy, the atomically dispersed Pt on carbon nanotube or CoP nanotube have been obtained without the formation of Pt particles.[27] In other work, single-atom Ni, Fe samples were obtained through adsorption of Ni and Fe ion on graphdiyne support, followed by electrochemical reduction.[28] Dual-site Co–Pt on N-doped carbon was obtained through electrochemical activation of asprepared CoNx sample.[29]
Wang et al.[30] provided an electrochemically assisted approach to synthesize isolated FeNx on few-layer graphene starting from graphite (N-Fe/G) (Figure 2). The graphite was first intercalated by FeCl4 based ionic liquid and simultaneously exfoliated to graphene. Meanwhile, an iron containing solid electrolyte interphase onto graphene surface was probably formed, which can provide the necessary Fe resource. After annealing at the presence of nitrogen source (melamine), atomic Fe was kept and coordinated with nitrogen to form isolated FeNx site into the graphene matrix.
Microwave-Assisted Method: Microwave (MW) irradiation has been introduced as a rapid and convenient method to prepare graphene by reduction of graphene oxide or expansion of graphite intercalated compound.[31] Most recently, the MW-assisted strategy has been also used to prepare atomic MNx (M = Co, Ni, Cu) site embedded in nitrogen-doped graphene by Fei et al.[32] In brief, the GO was first reacted with aqueous ammonia to prepare amine-functionalized GO (AGO) as carbon and nitrogen sources. The mixture of AGO and metal ion, together with small amounts of graphene as catalysts, was MW-irradiated with a conventional MW oven for 5 s under N2 atmosphere to obtain the final sample (Figure 3). The ultrafast MW heating process inhibited the metal agglomeration, thereby leading to the predominant presence of atomic metal species. This method may provide a common way to prepare graphene supported SACs in a fast, simple, and energy-saving manner.

sections.heading: 2.1.3. Ball Milling
sections.text: Ball milling has been utilized in low-cost and high-yield exfoliation and functionalization of graphite.[33] Interestingly, this method is also effective for the preparation of graphene supported SACs. Deng et al. found that the MN4 centers of corresponding metal phthalocyanine (MPc) (i.e., Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) can be successfully embedded into the graphene matrix via high-energy ball milling, instead of the formation of MPc/graphene composition through π–π interaction.[34] One proposed mechanism was also provided. During the high energy ball milling, the outside macrocyclic structure of MPc can be destroyed to form residual MN4 centers, which further interact with the graphene at the defect site to reconstruct the MN4 centers embedded into the graphene matrix. This method may reduce the structural disorder of the graphene support compared with pyrolyzed samples, and it benefits the identification of the single metal sites.

After melting under dark condition at room temperature, the as-prepared Pt solution was mixed with graphene support to obtain the final sample. sections.heading: 2.1.5. Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD)
sections.text: ALD technique has been used to controll fabrication of Pt, Co, and Pd single atom on graphene or N-doped graphene.[37] Yan et al. reported the use of graphene oxide and Co(C5H5)2 as precursor to prepare Co single-atom embedded into graphene defect based on ALD.[8a] The sample was exposed to ozone (O3) after each ALD cycle, which can not only remove the residual organic ligands but also create epoxy functional group on graphene to act as new anchor sites, thus realizing the controlled loading of SACs.

sections.heading: 2.2. SACs in Graphitic Carbon Nitride
sections.text:
g-C3N4, an analogue of graphite constructed through the sp2 hybridization of carbon and nitrogen atoms, is another widely studied 2D support for SACs. Different from graphene, the abundant and uniform pyridine-like N component in g-C3N4 framework can be directly utilized as metal coordination sites. For g-C3N4 supported SACs, the ordered structure of g-C3N4 provides more precise information for the identification of catalytically active sites and plays an important role in tuning the electrocatalytic activity. Therefore, when design a synthetic route for g-C3N4 supported SACs, the structural maintenance of g-C3N4 should be taken into consideration.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. In Situ Synthesis
sections.text:
Various N-rich precursors can be polymerized to g-C3N4 with desirable crystallinity in the polymerization temperature within 475 to 600 °C. When incorporating a small amount of metal into the precursors, the g-C3N4 nanosheets doped with individual metal atoms can be facilely obtained. For instance, Sr, Co, and Fe doped g-C3N4 have been synthesized without defining the structure of the metal atoms in g-C3N4 matrix.[38] In a modified strategy reported by Chen et al., the as-prepared silver tricyanomethanide was used as a miscible and reactive metal precursor to cocondensation with cyanamide, which ensured the homogeneity of the single atom dispersed Ag coordinated with g-C3N4.[39] An et al. synthesized ultrasmall clusters and single atom Fe sites embedded in g-C3N4 through the pyrolysis of melamine and Fe salts at 600 °C.[40] In some thinner g-C3N4, only uniformly dispersed single-atom Fe can be found, as confirmed by high-angle annular dark field (HAADF) scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS).
Normally, the conductivity of g-C3N4 supported SACs should be further improved for electrocatalytic application. Zheng et al. used carbon nanotube as conductive substrate to prepare atom Co embed g-C3N4 (Co-C3N4/carbon nanotube (CNT)) through the pyrolysis of the mixture of CoCl2, dicyandiamide, and carbon nanotube at 600 °C.[9] Based on the identical method, Liu et al. further synthesized atomically dispersed Ni and Fe sites coexisting in g-C3N4 supported on carbon nanotube (Figure 4a).[41] Jiao et al. then extended the study to atom Cu doped g-C3N4 supported on conductive carbon black for electrochemical CO2RR.[42] Niu et al. provided another approach to enhance the electron transfer and electrocatalytic activity through the in situ introduction of crystalline carbon structure within g-C3N4 skeleton
(Figure 4b). In this work, the precursor mixture of melamine, lactose, Co(NO3)2, and NaCl underwent the first-step polymerization below 500 °C and then converted into Co coordinated g-C3N4 that comprised of crystalline carbons under 700 °C.[43]

sections.heading: 2.2.2. Wet Chemistry
sections.text: Wet chemistry method usually involves 1) the adsorption of metal ion on the C3N4 surface or edge defect by liquid phase stirring and then 2) reduction or bonding through reducing agent or low temperature heat treatment. This approach enables the preparation of g-C3N4 supported SACs in a relatively mild manner without serious structural damage of the support. It is also conducive to the uniform distribution of the metal center on g-C3N4 surface, because of the abundant coordination sites on g-C3N4 and efficient diffusion of metal ion under liquid phase condition. For instance, isolated Ru atom anchored on mesoporous carbon nitride (Ru-mpg-C3N4) was synthesized by mixing as-prepared mpg-C3N4 with RuCl3 under vigorous stirring for 24 h, followed by vacuum drying and annealing at 300 °C.[44] Other isolated metal atoms (Pd, Pt, and Ru) supported on g-C3N4 have also been obtained by similar method.[45] Except the heptazine based g-C3N4, isolated Pd atoms stabilized on other kinds of carbon nitrides, including melem oligomers and poly(triazine/heptazine imides), have been synthesized through wet chemistry approach.[46]

sections.heading: 2.3. MOFs and COFs Derived SACs
sections.text:
MOFs and COFs have been emerging as new porous materials featuring well-defined structure, tunable morphology,

The most attractive advantage of MOFs and COFs for SACs synthesis is the designability; that is, the structure of the building blocks can be controlled at molecular level to decide the type and corresponding chemical environment of the single metal sites. Moreover, to overcome the diffusion problem caused by their microporous structures, some research effort has been directed to the preparation of SACs based on 2D MOFs and COFs. In particular, remarkable progresses have been achieved for MOFs based SACs in recent years.[5,6c,47] Readers can refer to several excellent reviews on this topic.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Bottom-Up Synthesis
sections.text:
The atomically dispersed metal sites (usually Fe, Co, Ni, and Cu) exist in the nodes in pristine MOFs or can be anchored on the organic ligands of MOFs through post-treatments. These atomic Fe, Co, and Ni sites in MOFs have been demonstrated to have considerable activity for energy-related electrocatalytsis. Moreover, more than one kind of catalytically active components, including metal particles, organic molecule, and another single metal site, can be incorporated into one MOF, where the synergistic effect between them for enhanced electrocatalytic performance has gradually been found and explained. In a typical example, Zhao et al. synthesized Ni, Co based bimetallic-organic framework nanosheets (NiCo-UMOFNs) from a mixed solution of Ni2+, Co2+, and benzenedicarboxylic acid.[11] As demonstrated by XAS and the corresponding calculations, the coordinatively unsaturated metal
sites caused by the ultrathin nanosheet morphology, together with partial electron transformation from Ni2+ to Co2+, largely improved the electrochemical OER performance of NiCo-UMOFNs.
Similarly, the atomically dispersed metal sites can be introduced into COFs through two slightly different routes, that is, 1) selection of transition metal macrocyclic clusters as building blocks, including Co-, Fe-, Ni-, Cu-, and Zn-based porphyrin,[48] and phthalocyanine,[49] and 2) immobilization of single metal sites on heteroatom-containing COFs, such as the covalent triazine frameworks (CTFs). As for electrocatalytic application, the covalent bond linked frameworks with extend π conjugation usually endow COFs with better physicochemical stability and enhanced conductivity, both of which are highly required for ideal electrocatalysis. For example, Yi et al.[12a] reported atomically dispersed Fe sites within layered porphyrin-based COFs synthesized by cyclotrimerization reaction under ionothermal condition (Figure 5a). The porphyrin-like FeN4 configuration was unambiguously identified by X-ray absorption fine structure analyses and spherical aberration-corrected transmission electron microscope (TEM) (Figure 5b–d). In order to improve the conductivity for enhanced electrocatalytic performance, Pt, Fe, Cu, Pd, and Pt doped CTFs have been in situ polymerized on conductive carbon black or carbon nanotube by adding metal salt and conductive support to CTFs precursor during polymerization.[50] In these works, metal atoms were coordinated with the pyridine-N of triazine ring in CTFs skeleton. The existence of MN bond without corresponding MM bond was confirmed by X-ray adsorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectra, indicating that M exists in the form of a single atom.

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Carbonization
sections.text:
Carbonization of MOFs or COFs can convert them into carbonaceous frameworks with more stable singe-metal sites and better conductivity. Different from the pyrolysis of separate precursors, the precursors can been preliminarily arranged at molecular level in MOFs or COFs skeleton, which enable the realization of some novel SACs structures, such as high single-atom loading, high exposure of single-atom sites,[51] size-controllable SACs synthesis,[52] and multisite SACs with identified synergistic effect.[53]
Zn based MOFs have been emerged as a new platform for the synthesis carbon-supported SACs. For instance, Yin et al.[54] reported the synthesis carbon-supported Co SACs from bimetallic Zn/Co ZIFs. In a typical procedure, different ratios of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, Zn(NO3)2·6H2O, and 2-methylimidazole (MeIM) precursors were dispersed in methanol and then hydrothermally treated at 120 °C to obtain Co and Zn codoped ZIFs. The obtained samples went through pyrolysis under Ar atmosphere to obtain the final Co SACs. This method has many advantages, that is 1) the introduced Zn atom enlarges the adjacent distance of the target metal sites in MOFs, thus suppresses the metallic aggregates during pyrolysis, 2) the evaporation of Zn produces free N sites to stabilize the nonvolatile Co atom, and 3) in situ generates pores to improve mass
transfer. Using similar approach, Wu’s group synthesized the densely dispersed Fe and Co SACs on carbon support in the absence of metallic aggregates.[52,55] In addition, Chen et al.[56] and Zhao et al.[57] confined the target metal precursors within the cavities of Zn-based MOFs (ZIF-8) through in situ synthesis or ion-exchange, respectively, and then obtained carbonsupported Fe or Ni SACs by pyrolysis. Jiang et al.[58] further verified that the excessive iron phthalocyanine (FePc) in the cavities of ZIF-8 could aggregate into Fe2O3 during pyrolysis, subsequently induced the CN bond cleavage, thus leading to edge-hosted Fe–N4 moieties with higher ORR activities. Wang et al. anchored the Ru ions in the ligand of Zn-based MOFs (UiO-66–NH2) and obtained carbon-supported Ru SACs by pyrolysis.[59] Through the combination of above methods, Wang et al.[53] successfully fabricated atomically dispersed Fe–Co multisites without metal particle by-products by onestep pyrolysis of a Zn/Co ZIFs with FeCl3 incorporated in the cavities (Figure 6).
COFs could be also used as potential precursor for synthesis of atomically dispersed metal sites on carbonaceous support. The covalent-linked frameworks endow COFs with relatively high thermal stability, which lead to a closer structural association between COFs and its pyrolized derivatives.[60] We developed a series of sulfur-doped FeNx catalysts from covalent triazine frameworks and studied the relationship between

sections.heading: 2.4. SACS in Transition Metal Dichalcogenides (TMDs)
sections.text: 2D TMDs are promising SACs support for electrocatalytic application, as they are electrochemically active for HER and the sulfur vacancies in TMDs can anchor metal atom via the formation of MS bond. Recently, single-atom doping of TMDs has been demonstrated by both theoretical and experimental researches. The methods involved can be divided into two categories with slight differences. The first one is direct chemical synthesis via hydrothermal method. For instance, Deng et al. synthesized Pt single-atom doped MoS2 through a one-pot hydrothermal reaction of sodium molybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·4H2O) and chloroplatinic acid (H2PtCl6) using CS2 as solvent.[63] Xiong et al. synthesized cobalt-containing Mo2C through thermal treatment of (NH4)6Mo7O24, Co(NO3)2, and cellulose, then converted it into Co atom doped MoS2 by a vapor-phase hydrothermal method.[64] In other works, Mn atom doped MoS2 and Ni atom doped SnS2 have been obtained by hydrothermal method.[65] For another method, atom doped TMDs were obtained through doping metal atom into the as-prepared TMDs by calcination, such as the Co, Pt, and Ni atom doped MoS2 and WS2.[10,66] For example, Luo et al. synthesized Pd atom doped MoS2 through ultrasonic mixing of as-prepared MoS2 and Pd(OAc)2, followed by thermal treatment at 60 °C.[67] Wang et al. obtained Ni atom doped MoS2 supported on carbon cloth (CC) via thermal treatment of the mixture of as-obtained MoS2/CC and nickel chloride (NiCl2) at 600 °C under H2/Ar atmosphere.[68]

sections.heading: 3.1. Types of the Active Sites
sections.text:
The active sites of SACs fall into two categories, distinguished by whether the single-atomic metal center directly involves the chemical reaction. In most cases, individual metal atom can be stabilized by defect or heteroatoms on the supports and act as an independent active site. The catalytically activate metal centers are usually the transition metal elements due to their strong coordination ability and the unsaturated d orbital to adsorb and activate the reaction intermediates. However, these active sites cannot be treated as an isolated atom, as the catalytic activity always depends on the effect of coordination environment between the metal center and surrounding atoms of the supports. Therefore, this kind of active sites should include the atoms that directly coordinate with the central atom, such as the extensively studied MNx[52,57] and MCx[17,69] moieties. In some cases, two types of single atomic centers in adjacent position could exhibit strong synergistic effect and work together as dual-metal sites for electrocatalysis.[53] The MNx center also can synergize with nearby metal particle to boost the catalytic activity.[70]
In another situation, the single metal atom itself does not work as an active center but as a trigger to stimulate the intrinsic activity of nearby heteroatoms through strong interaction with the supports. The typical examples are the transition metal (Co, Ni, Pt, Pd, or Ir) doped MoS2 nanosheets.[64,65,67,71] The metal atom substitution occurred at the Mo site, which introduces the S vacancy as active site for electrochemical water splitting.

sections.heading: 3.2. Characterization Technologies
sections.text: To illustrate the modulation process of the electronic structures of SACs catalysts is crucial for the rational design of efficient electrocatalysts. Currently, the combination of atomic resolution aberration-corrected STEM and XAS has emerged as important and popular technique for atomic and electronic structures characterization of SACs, which have then been correlated with theoretical calculations for mechanistic interpretation.

sections.heading: 3.2.1. STEM
sections.text: The STEM enables the direct visualization of atomically dispersed metal atoms, as well as corresponding coordination atoms, on the supports via the difference in contrast, which can clearly distinguish the SACs sites from aggregative metal particles. The in situ STEM technology is also helpful to the study of formation mechanism of SACs sites. Most recently, Wei et al. directly observed the transformation process from noble metal (Pd, Au, and Pt) nanoparticles to thermally stable single atom during pyrolysis.[72] However, STEM image does not offer information about electronic interaction between metal center and the surrounding atoms.

sections.heading: 3.2.2. XAS
sections.text:
XAS[73] is a powerful technology for atomic and electronic structure study of SACs, generally involving XANES and EXAFS. The XANES is essentially a fingerprint technique that reflects the chemical state and the coordination symmetry of the absorbing atom. The EXAFS can provide information on the coordination number and bond distance with nearby coordination atoms.
Based on the XAS analysis, the details about however the coordination atoms modulate the electronic structure of the metal active center could be reflected. For example, Li et al. reported the Fe single atoms on sulfur and nitrogen codoped carbon (Fe-ISA/SNC) and provided a step-by-step clarification of the synergistic effect between FeNx sites and nearby S atom by XAS analysis.[74] Figure 7a shows the Fe K-edge XANES of Fe-ISA/SNC with Fe foil, FeO, Fe2O3 as references. We can see the valence of Fe species in Fe-ISA/SNC is situated between Fe2+ and Fe3+ through comparing with the FeO and Fe2O reference samples. The Fourier transform (FT) curve of EXAFS of Fe-ISA/SNC (panel (b)) shows a main peak corresponding to Fe–N moiety and the absence of Fe–O, Fe–S, and Fe–Fe moieties, confirming that the Fe atoms were coordinated by

N and atomically dispersed on the supports. Different from the Fe-ISA/NC sample without S doped that shows only one chemical state of Fe–N moiety, two Fe–N moieties with different bonding length are observed in Fe-ISA/SNC (Figure 7c). In addition, the valence of S atom in Fe-ISA/SNC is +1.2 based on the S K-edge XANES analysis (Figure 7d,e). And C–S–N binding is detected in X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) with the absence of oxidized S–O binding (binding energy of 166–171 eV) (Figure 7f). Thus, the charge transfer from S atom to N atom may be occurred due to the stronger electronegativity (3.04) of N compared to S (2.58). Based on the experimental information above, together with computational simulation, the chemical structure of the active site was proposed (Figure 10a). Due to the electron donation from the S atom, the metal center Fe becomes less positive, thus improving the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates.

sections.heading: 3.2.3. Theoretical Calculation
sections.text:
Besides the experimental techniques, theoretical calculations (e.g., DFT) are also important for understanding the catalytic reaction mechanisms and the structure–activity relationship of the SACs.[75] Based on the experimental structure information, DFT calculation can further confirm the thermodynamically stable structural models of the SACs. Also, it can illustrate the charge density distribution of SACs sites and determine the electron transfer process between active center and surrounding atoms. This information could be guidance for rational modulation of the electronic structure of SACs. Liu et al. revealed that the Pt atom embedded into divacancy graphene is the most stable configuration than
into monovacancy or anchored by four C atoms.[69] Yang et al. revealed that the higher ORR activity of FeN4 than Pt/C originates from the Fe–pyrrolic–N configuration rather than Fe–pyridinic–N configuration by using DFT calculation.[76] Hossain et al. suggested the HER activity of MN4 on graphene highly depends on the energy states of active valence dz2 orbitals and their resulting antibonding state of metal center.[77] The superior activity of CoN4 sites could be attributed to its location of 3dz2 valence orbital near to the Fermi level, together with the partially empty antibonding state, which can lead to an optimum adsorption strength toward hydrogen adsorption.

sections.heading: 4. Modulation of the Electronic Structure for SACs
sections.text: Modulating the electronic structure of the metal center is considered as a highly effective strategy for the enhancement in electrocatalytic activity of SACs. The methods include: 1) tuning the species of the metal center or corresponding coordination environment, 2) adjusting the loading position of the SACs on the supports (e.g., edge or base plane), and 3) changing the long-range atomic environment by heteroatom doping.

sections.heading: 4.1. Tuning the Metal Center or Coordination Environment
sections.text:
As the high activity of transition metals largely originates from their unsaturated d orbital, changing the active metal center is the most direct way to modulate the electronic structure of the SACs sites. Various metal centers on the same support can exhibit obvious active difference for electrocatalysis,

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800438 (11 of 28)
which have been proved by experimental results[28] (e.g., graphdiyne supported Fe and Ni SACs) and DFT calculations[78] (e.g., C2N monolayers supported Ti, Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mo, Ru, Rh, Pd, Ag, Ir, Pt, or Au SACs). Several kinds of MN4C4 sites on graphene (M = Co, Fe, and Ni) with definitely identical coordination environment have been developed and exhibited different electrochemical performance toward OER reaction, attributed to the various adsorption free energies for the intermediates OH*.[8b]
For specific metal center, the active difference highly depends on the charge redistribution caused by the difference in the electronegativity with coordination atoms. Therefore, changing the coordination atoms is also worked for electronic modulation of SACs. Up to now, several modulation methods have been reported to show improved electrocatalytic activity, including adjusting the number and type of coordination atoms, introducing heteroatoms nearby the SACs sites, grafting heteroatoms on metal center, and constructing dual-metal sites. The active enhancement after structure modification is discussed in the next section. For rational design, the electronegativity of coordination atoms can be an indicator for the modulation of charge density of the metal center. However, to confirm how the charge density change of the active center influences the final electrochemical reaction is another challenge. Recently, preliminary success has been achieved on this aspect, involving the electronic modulation of FeN4 sites for improved ORR performance. Chen et al. synthesized S and P codoped carbon with FeN4 site (Fe-SAs/NPS-C) and studied the electronic structure change after heteroatom doping.[79] The DFT calculation revealed that the last step of 4e− ORR (*OH + 3OH− + e− → 4OH− + *) on FeN4 was the rate-limiting step at the equilibrium potential, due to the too strong adsorption of *OH (Figure 8a). The charge density differences and Bader charge analysis of S and P codoped FeN4 sites reveal that the electron can transfer from S and P to Fe center of FeN4 and make it become less positive (Figure 8b–e), which weakens the adsorption free energy of OH* and thereby improving the ORR performance.

sections.heading: 4.2. Adjusting the Site Location
sections.text: The heteroatom at edge of the support can have different electronic properties with that in in-plane, due to the influence of dangling bonds. As the electronic structure of SACs highly depends on the coordination environment, the coordination of metal center with heteroatoms on edge or in-plane can also influence the electronic structure and catalytic activity of SACs. Besides, the geometric configuration of SACs at edge is more easily accessible, which can lower the adsorption barriers of the intermediates. For example, Jiang et al. revealed the edge-N atoms could affect the charge density distribution of FeN4 site, as well as the intermediates adsorption configurations.[58] The edge-hosted Fe–N4 moieties show lower reaction barriers over the whole oxygen reduction process comparing to intact atomic configuration. Through theoretical calculation and experimental results, Pan et al. elucidated that the CO2RR activity of edge-hosted M–N2+2–C8 (M = Co or Fe) moieties is much higher than the MN4 moieties embedded compactly in a graphitic in-plane.[80] During the CO2RR, the M centers and C atoms with dangling bonds next to N respectively act as the active sites to adsorb *CO and *OH in the cleavage of CO bond.

sections.heading: 4.3. Changing the Long-Range Atomic Environment
sections.text:
The 2D materials normally have extensively delocalized electronic structure, which makes it possible to modulate the longrange electronic structure of the whole support by heteroatom doping. Besides the intrinsic activity, the conductivity of support of SACs is also important for electrocatalytic reaction. In the work by Cao et al., the g-C3N4 supported CoNx catalyst with P doping exhibits much improved kinetic activity toward HER reaction, which could be attributed to the enhanced electrical conductivity of the support.[81] Another example is the Pd or Ir atom doped MoS2 nanosheets.[67,71] The doped Pd or Ir atom

sections.heading: 5. Electrocatalytic Performance
sections.text:
In the following section, we introduce and summarize the energy-related electrochemical application of SACs and focus on the modulation of electronic structure of SACs for enhanced performance. The 2D materials supported SACs that involve
the electronic modulation, as well as detailed catalytic applications are summarized in Table 1.

sections.heading: 5.1. ORR
sections.text:
ORR is the core electrochemical process in clean energy conversion devices, including rechargeable metal–air batteries and fuel cells. The ORR is a multistep reaction processing via either four electron (4e−) pathways (O2 + 4H+ + 4e− → 2H2O), desired by fuel cell cathode, or two-step two-electron (2e−) pathways (O2 + 2H+ + 2e− → H2O2), required by clean production
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800438 (13 of 28)
of H2O2. The conventional Pt catalysts are well-known to be highly efficient for ORR with 4e− reaction pathways. But the situation can be very different when loading single-atom Pt into different coordination environments. For instance, Choi et al. reported the single-atom Pt embedded into S-doped graphene matrix with PtS4 structure. The resulting catalyst showed a high yield of H2O2, indicating 2e− reaction pathways of ORR, consistent with the result from single Pt atoms supported on TiN.[19a,82] It is explained that the electrocatalysis on PtS4 is controlled by kinetics that favors the 2e− reduction of oxygen, as the reorganization energy for the 2e− pathways is significantly smaller than that for the 4e− pathway. By contrast, the single Pt atom anchored on single-pyridine N atom within carbon support (Pt1-N/BP) reported by Liu et al. exhibited the reduction of O2 was dominated by 4e− pathway.[83] The absence of aggregated Pt as observed by EXAFS and sub-angstrom resolution HAADF-STEM, together with the unusual CO and methanol tolerance, confirmed the single-atomic characteristic for Pt1-N/BP. As shown by DFT calculations, the low H2O2 yield can be explained by the easier breaking of OO bond on Pt1-N/BP caused by the stronger adsorption of O2 on single Pt atom than on traditional bulk Pt sites. In another work with single-atomic Ru on nitrogen-doped graphene, similar experimental phenomena and theoretical explanations have also been provided.[22a]
M-N/C catalysts are considered as promising alternatives for noble metal-based ORR catalysts due to high performance and low cost. But its real active site, however, has long been in dispute.[84] Until recently, the single atomic nature of the active site was gradually demonstrated. To be specific, the MNx moieties supported on carbon matrix are one class of the ORR sites with the highest catalytic activity. For specific metal centers, the coordination environment modulates the electronic density of the single-atom active sites, which significantly influences its adsorption energy for the catalytic intermediates and, therefore, determines their electrocatalytic performance. Indeed, various MNx configurations have been proposed and verified their high ORR activity. For instance, Zitolo et al. revealed two pyrroletype FeN4 configurations with one or two O2 adsorbed on Fe center in side-on or end-on mode, respectively (Figure 9a).[13] These structures are different from the pyridinic-N-based MN4C8 architecture in other work (Figure 9b).[8b] Chen et al.[56] synthesized single-atomic Fe-ISAs/CN catalysis and suggested the Fe atom was coordinated with four N atoms, accompanied by one O2 perpendicularly adsorbed on it (Figure 9c). In 0.1 m KOH, the half-wave potentials of the Fe-ISAs/CN reached 0.9 V, which is 58 mV more positive than commercial Pt/C. Through DFT calculations, Shen et al.[85] suggested the FeN2 configuration outperforms FeN4 due to its lower interaction with *O2 and *OH intermediates and enhanced electron transport (Figure 9d). Also, they prepared FeN2/NOMC catalysts with the N coordination number to be two, as confirmed by EXAFS and 57Fe Mössbauer spectroscopy. The FeN2/NOMC-3 exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.863 V in 1 m KOH, ≈30 mV more positive than commercial Pt/C. Furthermore, the work by Yin et al. revealed the dominant coordination number of CoNx sites converted from four to two with increased pyrolysis temperature from 800 to 900 °C, accompanied by the increase in ORR activity.[54] Similar temperature-activity trends for FeNx and
CoNx in acidic medium were observed by Wu and co-workers, but the N coordination number likely remained at four with increased temperature.[52,55] The control experiments about the ORR activity suggested that 800 °C is the minimum temperature for generating active sites in acidic media. A higher temperature (up to 1100 °C) leads to enhanced activity, which likely facilitates the formation of a larger number of FeN4 sites, as well as more graphitic N component.[52] Particularly, under challenging acidic condition, their optimized FeN4 catalyst (ZIF-Fe) achieved an E1/2 of 0.85 V, only 30 mV lower than Pt/C benchmark. They speculated the adjacent graphitic N might generate a synergy to promote the adsorption of O2 and OO bond breaking on FeN4 sites, although no explicit DFT discussion was proposed.
It is well-known that the sites at edge or defect of heterogeneous catalysts have the highest catalytic activity. The work by Jiang et al.[58] verified that it remains applicable to support SACs. Using in situ formed metal Fe by-product to catalyze the adjacent CN bond cleavage of FeN4 sites (Figure 9e), they successfully obtained edge-hosted FeN4 moieties (Fe-SAs-N/C), as proved by 13C solid state nuclear magnetic resonance (ssNMR) measurements and DFT calculation (Figure 9f,g). Specifically, ssNMR showed the N-alkyl carbons resonance of Fe-SAs-N/C largely increased when adding excessive amount of Fe resource during pyrolysis, and DFT results revealed the CN bond adjacent to FeN4 sites is more vulnerable than C–C bond in graphene frameworks, indicating that the FeN4 moiety with edge-N is thermodynamically favorable (Figure 9h). The optimized Fe-SAs-N/C-20 exhibited high metal utilization efficiency and fast mass transport, with a potential (E1/2) of 0.915 V and superior diffusion-controlled current density to that of Pt/C in 0.1 m KOH.
The above examples indicate that the neighboring atomic environment significantly influences the ORR activity of the isolated metal atoms. In a broader sense, the intrinsic activity of MNx moieties highly depends on the synergy between the single metal atoms and the supports.[86] It was found that the addition of sulfur to the precursor gave an M-N/C catalyst with enhanced ORR or fuel cell performance, but the mechanisms involved were still controversial.[87] Recently, Shen et al. studied the synergistic effects between the FeN2 sites and the doped S in the graphene support.[24c,88] In 0.5 m H2SO4, the S-doped FeN2 catalyst exhibited a half-wave potential of 0.77 V, ≈30 mV more positive than that of sulfur-free sample. They proposed that the thiophene-like S could reduce the electron localization around the Fe centers, which improves the interaction with oxygenated species, and therefore facilitates the complete 4e− ORR under acidic condition. Similar results have been also obtained under alkaline condition.[74,89] Using pyrrole–thiophene copolymer as precursor, Li et al. successfully realized the FeN4 sites on S-doped carbon (Fe-ISA/SNC) with controllable S content.[74] ORR reactivity of Fe-ISA/SNC showed a volcano curve with the increase of sulfur doping (Figure 10a–c). DFT calculation revealed that the S atoms lost one electron to adjacent N atoms of FeNx to form FeN4S2 active center, due to the stronger electronegativity of N (3.04) than S (2.58). The enriched charge of N atoms surrounding the FeN4 sites facilitates the rate-limiting reductive release of OH* and therefore improves the ORR efficiency. Recently, boron (B) doping has been demonstrated to

© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800438 (14 of 28)
give similar affect.[90] In another work, Han et al.[91] revealed that the electronic structure of the FeN4 active center supported on S-doped carbon can be further modulated through the coordination with one chlorine atom (FeCl1N4/CNS). The simulation for EXAFS reveals that the Fe in the FeCl1N4/CNS is coordinated by a Cl atom and four N atoms (Figure 10d,e). A new doublet D4 peak was also found in Mössbauer spectroscopy, which can be assigned to the Fe–Cl species. The FeCl1N4/ CNS exhibited excellent E1/2 of 0.921 V, which is the highest among the reported values for nonprecious metal electrocatalysts under alkaline condition (Figure 10f). Similar modulation strategy has been reported to improve activity and stability of FeN4 sites toward ORR via a “single-atom to single-atom” grafting of a Pt atom onto the Fe center through a bridging oxygen molecule.[92] Construction of dual-metal sites has emerged as an efficient approach to modulate the electronic structure of single-atom sites for enhanced ORR performance. In fact, the improved performance toward fuel cell of Fe, Co bimetallic M-N/C catalyst than its single metal counterpart has previously been proved.[93] The work by Wang et al.[53] provided an atomic insight into the synergistic effect between different single-metal sites. A one-step pyrolysis of Fe-, Co-, and Zn-containing MOFs was employed to obtain the N-coordinated dual-metal sites (FeCo)/ NC embedded graphene matrix. The combination of EXAFS results and DFT simulation suggested the (Fe, Co)/N-C adopted an unusual dual metal center rather than isolated single Fe and Co sites, in which the FeN3 and its neighboring CoN3 configuration were linked by FeCo bond to constitute a deformed porphyrin-like structure (Figure 11a). Surprisingly, superior
Small Methods 2019, 1800438
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800438 (15 of 28)
ORR performance to commercial Pt/C under acidic condition was achieved for (FeCo)/NC catalysis. Its onset potential and half-wave potential reached 1.06 and 0.863 V, respectively, both are higher than those of Pt/C (1.03 and 0.858 V) (Figure 11b). Density functional theory calculations reveal the dual sites can reduce the cleavage energy of OO bond, facilitate the fourelectron oxygen reduction, and thus improve the ORR catalytic performance. Importantly, the (FeCo)/NC was further applied as cathode to proton-exchange membrane fuel cell and exhibited comparable activity to Pt/C in both H2/O2 and H2/air working conditions (Figure 11c,d). In constant-current operation tests at 600 and 1000 mA cm−2, its working voltage shows negligible loss after 100 h, indicating its potential in automotive industry (Figure 11e,f). In another work, Zhang et al.[29] synthesized a CoPt coupling dual-metal sites located at the interstice of the graphitic layers via the electrochemical activation of the as-prepared Co single-atom sample (A-CoPt-NC). Based on the observation result of HAADF-STEM images, combined with DFT simulation, the configuration of the CoPt sites was proposed to be (CoPt)@N8V4, where N8 represents the number of nitrogen atoms and V4 indicates the number of vacant carbon atoms (Figure 12a). DFT calculations suggested that the special coordination structure of (CoPt)@N8V4 triggered the charge redistribution between Pt atom and Co atom, which benefits the activation of O2 and thus enhancing the ORR performance (Figure 12b–e).
Except Fe and Co, other transition metal-based SACs also exhibited good ORR activities. For instance, Yang et al.[94] synthesized O and N atoms coordinated Mn single atom incorporated within graphene frameworks and proved that a
coordinated O atom can play a significant role in tuning the intrinsic ORR activities of transition metals. Li et al.[95] reported the synthesis of a Cu single-atom catalyst with high Cu loading over 20.9 wt%. During oxygen reduction, the single atomic Cu exhibited over 54 times higher mass activity and 3.2 times higher kinetic current than metallic Cu nanoparticles at a potential of 0.85 V.

sections.heading: 5.2. OER
sections.text:
The electrocatalytic OER is the reverse reaction of the ORR, which occurs in water splitting or the recharging process of the metal–air batteries. Recent research works revealed that the bimetallic nodes in MOFs frameworks of ultrathin 2D structure are highly electrochemically active for OER. On one hand, the ultrathin 2D morphology led to many coordinatively unsaturated metal sites of enhanced catalytic activity, probably attributed to their more filled 3d eg states than the fully coordinated ones.[11,96] On the other hand, the charge transfer between different metal nodes tunes their electronic structures, which further enhance the ORR activity by optimizing the adsorption energy of both metal sites for reaction intermediates.[11,97] Up to now, the Ni–Co, Ni–Fe, and Co–Fe based mixed nodes MOFs have been synthesized and exhibited much enhanced OER activity that is even superior to IrO2 benchmark.[11,97,98] Using glassy carbon (GC) electrode as collector, a low overpotential of 283 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2 was achieved for the Co–Fe based MOFs in 0.1 m KOH solution.[98a] This value further decreased to 225 mA cm−2 when replacing GC with Cu

In 1 m KOH solution, the overpotential of Ni–Co based MOFs coated on GC electrode was only 250 mV at 10 mA cm−2 with a small Tafel slope of 42 mV dec−1.[11] In another work, Huang et al.[98b] showed that a kind of layered Co based MOFs can be electrochemically exfoliated into 2D MOFs nanosheets and underwent Fe doping in FeSO4 solution, both processes can largely enhance its OER performance. The final Fe:2D-CoNS@Ni electrocatalyst coated on Ni foam exhibited an ultralow overpotential of 211 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a low Tafel slope of 46 mV dec−1. Despite the reports for stability enhancement of MOFs through doping or post-treatment,[98c,99] most of the MOFs based OER electrocatalysts still suffer from the stability problem due to its coordinatively linked nature. The COFs constructed by covalent bonds may have inborn advantage with respect to catalytic stability. In addition, the molecular catalysts of well-proved OER activity can be easily induced into COFs to act as active sites. Therefore, some kinds of Co porphyrin or Co modified COFs materials have been synthesized and showed to have good activity and stability toward OER.[100] The MNx (M = Fe, Co, Ni, and Mn) sites are also proved to be effective for OER.[16b,101] Like ORR, the electronic structure and coordination environment play important roles to determine the OER performance. Chen et al.[102] carried out DFT calculation to reveal that the pyridine-like nitrogen on graphene can induce positive charge density on atomic Co active site, which benefits the adsorption of OH− intermediates for enhanced OER activity. The Co atom coordinated with one N atom is the optimum configuration, more N coordination leads to activity decline because of too strong adsorption of reaction intermediates. Fei et al.[8b] revealed the OER activity and reaction pathways of MN4C4 (M = Fe, Co, and Ni) are highly dependent on the metal center (Figure 13a,b). For the FeN4C4 and CoN4C4 sites, all intermediates were found to be more strongly adsorbed on the metal center than the adjacent C atom (another possible

For NiN4C4 site, both Ni and C were involved in reaction via dual-site mechanism, because the O* and OH* are favorably adsorbed on C atom and OOH* is likely adsorbed on Ni atom. Furthermore, the unambiguous single metal site structure as well as the relatively ordered graphene support made the OER performance from DFT prediction (Ni > Co > Fe) matched well with the experimental result (Figure 13c,d). The overpotential at 10 mA cm−2 and Tafel slop of the best NiN4C4 sample were tested to be 331 mV and 63 mV dec−1, respectively. The experimental results from Li et al.[103] revealed the N-doped carbon with atomic Co/Ni dual sites exhibited higher OER activity than its Co or Ni single site counterpart, but the influence from metal particles was not excluded. Similar to MNx, OER activity of the single metal atom coordinated with C atom (MCx) has been investigated by theoretical and experimental studies. The ab initio study by Gao et al.[104] indicated that the high-coordinated transition metal atoms (Ni, Mn, Fe, Co, Cu, and Pd) on graphene matrix have higher activity than their lowcoordinated counterpart by contrasting the energy barriers of rate-determining step. And the NiC4 configuration exhibits the best OER performance. The work by Zhang et al.[17] experimentally demonstrated the high OER activity for NiC4 site, with a small overpotential of 270 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and a Tafel slopes of 47 mV dec−1 in 1 m KOH solution. Among the carbonaceous support of SACs, the g-C3N4 has advantage in high structural order and dense N coordination sites, which benefits the active site identification and reaction mechanism study. According to the DFT calculation, the Co atom anchored on g-C3N4 may have the best OER performance.[105] Zheng et al.[9] synthesized the Co-C3N4 supported on CNT (Co-C3N4/CNT) and studied its structure and OER activity. The Co atom might be embedded within a void in g-C3N4 and coordinated with two adjacent pyridinic-N atoms from two separate triazine units due to its lowest relative energy. In addition, the synergistic effect of atomically Ni, Fe dualmetal sites on g-C3N4 (NiFe@g-C3N4/CNT) had been explored by Liu et al.[41] As shown in Figure 14a,b, the NiFe@g-C3N4/CN exhibited smaller overpotential and Tafel slop than the single Ni or Fe doped samples. The enlarged Ni L3 edge XANES spectra in Figure 12c,d revealed two distinct peaks A1 (853.2 eV) and A2 (854.6 eV), corresponding to a low chemical state (Ni2+) and a more oxidative state (Ni3+), respectively. The peak intensity ratio of A2/A1 for NiFe@g-C3N4/CNTs increased compared with the single Ni metal doped Ni@g-C3N4/CNTs, and the opposite trend was observed in Fe L edge XANES spectra. These results demonstrated the partial charge transfer between Fe and Ni sites, and the enhanced OER performance could be attributed to the electronic structure reconfiguration.
In some cases, the carbonaceous SACs electrocatalysts of OER activity are simultaneously effective for ORR, which can serve as bifunctional oxygen electrocatalysis for metal–air batteries. Several FeNx or CoNx supported on N-doped graphene have been employed as electrode materials for rechargeable Zn–air battery.[26,106] Guo et al.[107] reported the boron (B) doping of CoNx based electrocatalyst to improve the ORR and OER performances. DFT calculation suggested that the B atom adjacent to Co atom provides positive influence on the charge density distribution of CoNx sites, which was believed to promote ORR and OER activities. However, the exact reason for the enhanced activity remained elusive, because the contribution from B-doped C sites cannot be excluded. Li et al.[25] synthesized dual-sites FeCo–Nx supported on hierarchically porous carbon (meso/micro-Fe–Nx–CN) and obtained excellent electrocatalytic activities with an exceptionally low Egap of 0.78 V between ORR half-wave potential and OER potential at a current density of 10 mA cm−2, much lower than that of commercial Pt/C. sections.heading: 5.3. HER
sections.text:
Electrochemical water splitting via HER is a clean and sustainable route to obtain hydrogen. The HER process can occur through either Volmer–Heyrovsky mechanism (H+ + e− + * → H*; H* + H+ + e− → H2 + *) or Volmer–Tafel mechanism (H+ + e− + * → H*; 2H* → H2 + 2*). Regardless of the reaction mechanism, H* (* denotes a site on the electrode surface) is the only catalytic intermediate involved. Therefore, the hydrogen adsorption free energy (ΔGH) can act as a descriptor for HER activity. With a nearly zero ΔGH, Pt locates very close to the top of the volcano plot and thus has been considered as the best HER catalyst.
Developing the SACs can maximize the utilization efficiency of Pt for cost saving. Besides, the surrounding environments significantly influence the electronic structure of Pt center and thus regulating the HER activities. It has been demonstrated that the isolated Pt atom can either be stabilized on the surface, edge, and defect of graphene matrix via interaction between Pt atom and C atom, or coordinated with the N atom on the N-doped graphene. Tavakkoli et al.[27a] used an electroplating deposition method to load isolated Pt atom on the perfect single-walled carbon nanotube (SWNT) surface (SWNT/Pt) with superior mass activity to Pt/C benchmark. The DFT calculation suggested that the adsorption energy of atomic Pt on SWNT is more energetically favorable than on the graphene surface, indicating the better antiagglomeration capacity of SWNT/Pt. Using an iced photochemical reduction method, Wei et al.[35] synthesized the isolated Pt atom on undoped porous carbon and achieved a superior volume activity to Pt/C catalyst. DFT calculation revealed the Pt atom can be stabilized on the edge and vacancy defect of the porous carbon (MC) support, whereas the Pt dimers is more easily formed on the defect-free region due to energetically favorable formation energy (Figure 16a). The resultant SACs showed a better mass activity, lower Tafel slop, and higher stability than commercial Pt/C (Figure 16b,c). The ΔGH values for three possible sites, the Pt atom anchored on single vacancy (PtSV), divacancy (PtDV), and edge (PtEdge), were calculated to be −0.049, 0.080, and −0.075 eV, respectively, all slightly closer to zero than that of Pt/C (Figure 16d). The enhanced HER activity mainly originated from the modulated electronic properties of Pt single atoms on MC support. It was found that the 5d orbitals of the PtSV partly overlapped with the C 2p orbitals around the Fermi level (Figure 16e), and partial charge would transfer from Pt atom to C atom. The charge transition led to more unoccupied 5d orbitals of Pt atom, which

sections.heading: 5.4. CO2RR
sections.text:
The non-noble metal based MNx catalysts are of great potential for high-selective electrochemical reduction of CO2 to CO.[21a,57,112] The proposed mechanism involves 1) the formation of *COOH intermediate via proton-coupled single electron transfer reaction for CO2 activation (CO2 + H+ + e− + * → *COOH), then 2) the combination of *COOH with another electron and proton to produce absorbed *CO and H2O (*COOH + H+ + e− → *CO + H2O), followed by 3) the desorption of CO. Similarly, the different metals in MNx exhibit various behaviors in CO2RR.
Based on experimental and theoretical results, many research works suggested that the CO2RR performance of MNx follows the trend of Ni ≥ Fe > Co.[113] This can be explained by the difference in binding energy of various metals with the reduction intermediates. Ju et al.[113a] compared the trends in the experimental CO-specific turnover frequencies (TOF) of the five MNx catalysts (Ni, Fe, Co Mn, and Cu) at different working potentials (Figure 18). At low overpotential region (<0.5 V), the Ni sample exhibited much higher onset potential for CO production than Fe sample. This means a larger thermodynamic driving force is needed to trigger the CO2 activation (step (1)), attributed to weaker *COOH absorption energy for Fe sample. At intermediate overpotential region (0.5–0.7 V), the rate-controlling intermediate has shifted from COOH* to CO* (step (2)), where Fe sample approached its activity limit for CO2RR because of the competitive H* absorption to catalyze HER. The Co sample exhibited low CO2RR activity because it is highly efficient for HER, while the Ni sample continued to increase

The in situ Ni K-edge XANES and EXAFS spectra revealed that the CO2RR to CO involved the charge transfer from Ni(i) to the carbon 2p orbital in CO2 as well as the recovery of low-oxidation-state Ni after one cycle of CO2 reduction. The A-Ni-NSG exhibited more than 100 mV lower reduction onset potential than S-free sample, which was ascribed to the lowered adsorption energy of intermediates on the catalyst surface induced by S doping. Yan et al.[115] experimentally investigated the CO2RR performance of coordinatively unsaturated NiNx sites. The DFT results identified the divacancy NiN2V2 moiety to be the high active CO2RR site, as it has suitable adsorption energies of *COOH as well as high activation barrier of H*. Besides, Wang et al.[116] synthesized N coordination-numbercontrollable CoNx samples through annealing at different temperatures. Experimental results showed that the reduction activity of CO2 to CO can be triggered if the N coordination number of CoNx sites decreased from 4 to 2 (Figure 19a–c), which was ascribed to facilitate the activation of CO2 to the *CO2− intermediate (Figure 19d). sections.heading: 5.5. NRR
sections.text:
The electrochemical NRR (N2 + 6H+ + 6e− → 2NH3) is a promising route for achieving clean and sustainable NH3 production
under ambient conditions. DFT calculation is helpful to identify the activity of single-atom metal on 2D materials with welldefined structure. Up to now, various kinds of 2D materials supported SACs have been theoretically predicted to be effective for electrochemical NRR, including Mo[121] atom on defective boron nitride, Ti[122] and V[122] atom on N-doped graphene, or Ti[123] and W[124] atom on g-C3N4.
Recently, the electrocatalytic NRR activity of SACs has been experimentally verified. Geng et al. reported the Ru SACs on N-doped carbon (Ru SAs/N-C) to achieve a high yield of 120.9 µg h−1 mg−1 cat. at −0.2 V in 0.05 m H2SO4 solution, which is much higher than that of Ru particle. It also showed good stability, with less than 7% decay of NH3 yield during 12 h potentiostatic test. Based on N2 temperature-programmed desorption and DFT calculation, the author revealed that the coordination of Ru with N atom can enhance the adsorption energy for N2 molecule, thus improving the reaction activity. Except the noble-atom SACs, the Mo[125] and Fe[126] based SACs have recently been studied for electrocatalytic NRR and exhibit competitive activities.

sections.heading: 6. Summary and Outlook
sections.text:
As an emerging electrocatalyst of high performance in the past few years, the 2D nanomaterials supported SACs have exhibited great potential for next-generation clean energy systems. Since the metal active center has reached the adjustable limits in terms of composition, shape, and size, the unique
© 2019 WILEY-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA, Weinheim1800438 (25 of 28)
Small Methods 2019, 1800438
electronic structure and catalytic behavior of SACs, in fact, originate from the corresponding coordination environment and the properties of the support. In this review, we have summarized the suitable synthetic strategies of SACs on different 2D supports, including pyrolysis, wet chemistry, external field-assisted approach, in situ synthesis, and MOFs or COFs derived routes. The methods that facilitate the formation of relative homogeneous structure and enable the regulation of the surrounding atomic environment of metal center have been highlighted. Furthermore, we reviewed recent progress of SACs for energy-related electrochemical reaction, including ORR, OER, HER, CO2RR, and NRR with particular emphasis on the strategies about modulation of the electronic structure of SACs for enhanced performance, such as introduction of second ligand on metal center, tuning the coordination environment from support, and changing the long-range electronic structure.
Despite the initial success, many challenges remain in the research of SACs. Although the preparation of SACs on 2D support has been extensively explored, the involved methods are mainly focused on the high-temperature pyrolysis. In this harsh condition, the structure of many 2D materials can be destroyed and the SACs sites tend to agglomerate. A mild and commonly applicable method for control of SACs is highly desired. Although preliminary progress has been achieved, research toward modulation of the electronic structure is still at its early stages. Many electrocatalytic processes are complicated multistep reaction, which means the single site may not realize optimal activation for all intermediates. Construction of dual-metal sites has certain potential in this aspect. However, accurately dispersing different kinds of singe atom sites into adjacent positions on the support, rather than random distribution, is still a challenging problem.
Elucidating the real structure of these active sites, as well as a deeper insight into the structure–activity relationship, is necessary to realize the rational design of high-performance electrocatalysts. Currently, many characterizations are operated in ex situ condition, which may not reflect the real structure–activity relationship. Monitoring atomic and electronic structure changes of SACs under realistic working conditions is crucial for the better understanding of the active sites and reaction mechanism, thus paving the way for rational design of efficient electrocatalysts. As shown in some cited examples above, due to extensive electron delocalization, the influence of the 2D supports to the catalytic activity of SACs is not merely dependent on the neighboring atoms of the metal center. More accurate theoretical calculations are therefore needed to help understand the long-range interaction between SACs sites and the supports. To this end, extensive research efforts should be contributed on advanced characterization technologies of atomic resolution and effective computational methods, especially the combination of both in future research.
